nodes.text: Modifying random forest via class weighting or balanced down-sampling improves prediction of the minority class in extremely imbalanced classification problems
Random forest as standard ensemble tends to minimize overall error and thus underperforms on minority class in extremely imbalanced data

Balanced Random Forest (BRF): for each tree draw a bootstrap sample of minority cases and an equal-size bootstrap sample of majority cases, grow unpruned CART trees with random mtry splits, aggregate by majority vote

Weighted Random Forest (WRF): assign larger misclassification weight to minority class, incorporate weights in Gini split criterion and in terminal node weighted majority vote, tune weights via out-of-bag accuracy

Experimental protocol: evaluated BRF and WRF on six highly imbalanced datasets using ten-fold cross validation and multiple metrics including true positive rate, true negative rate, precision, recall, F-measure, G-mean, weighted accuracy and ROC
Datasets used include oil spill, mammography, satimage, hypothyroid, euthyroid, and KDD thrombin, with minority class proportions ranging roughly 2 to 10 percent

On the oil spill data BRF and WRF with tuned parameters substantially improved minority-class performance compared to One-sided Sampling, SHRINK and SMOTE variants (e.g., WRF weight proportional to class yields high recall and improved G-mean and weighted accuracy)

On mammography and satimage datasets WRF and BRF achieved generally higher F-measure, G-mean and weighted accuracy than SMOTE and SMOTEBoost in many parameter settings, though performance tradeoffs between minority and majority accuracy occur

On hypothyroid and euthyroid datasets both BRF and WRF outperformed SHRINK, C4.5 and 1-NN by G-mean, with BRF slightly better in G-mean and weighted accuracy and WRF slightly better in F-measure in reported experiments
ROC analyses across datasets show BRF and WRF produce very similar ROC curves with no consistent winner; WRF slightly superior on some datasets and BRF on others
BRF is computationally more efficient on large imbalanced data because each tree uses a small balanced subsample, reducing per-tree training cost
WRF may be more vulnerable to label noise because assigning large weight to minority class amplifies effects of mislabeled majority cases treated as minority

Overall conclusion: both Balanced Random Forest and Weighted Random Forest improve minority-class prediction and outperform many existing techniques on tested datasets, but no clear universally superior method is identified
Limitation: inability to declare a clear winner between BRF and WRF and need for further study of robustness under label noise and other practical constraints
